newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: PRESS DIGEST - CZECH REPUBLIC - JUNE 27.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - CZECH REPUBLIC - JUNE 27.

text.p: HOSPODARSKE NOVINY - The Czech National Bank dropped its Lombard rate effective today to 23 percent from 50 percent, due to the gradual stabilisation of financial markets.

- Before laws restricting banks from controlling industrial holdings are approved, the National Property Fund wants to push banks to divest their current stakes in the firms. To this end, it said it will use direct regulation in Komercni Banka, Ceska Sporitelna and CSOB in which it holds a stake.

- Vseobecna Stavebni Sporitelna Komercni Banka had profits last year of 46.3 million crowns and expects similar results this year. During this year, there has been an increase in the construction savings bank's credits.
- While RadioMobil invested 2.5 billion crowns into developing its Paegas mobile telephone network, this year it will invest around five billion crowns.

- Representatives of Ceskomoravske Doly and Nova Hut signed two strategic documents, valid until 2002. The first is an agreement for cooperation in supplying coal and cooperation in companies in which they have stakes. Nova Hut will take 500,000 tonnes of coal from Ceskomoravske Doly this year.

MLADA FRONTA DNES - After talks between doctors and insurance companies, it is still uncertain how they will be paid for examinations, a decision which needs to be made by July 1, otherwise patients could end up paying much more for health care.

- A supreme court in Olomouc yesterday ruled that Ceska Pojistovna did not misuse its dominant position when it issued "green cards", advantageous for its clients. The Anti-monopoly Office issued the insurance company a fine of one million crowns for this.

- Last year, the Anti-monopoly Office punished companies and cooperatives with fines of more than 31 million crowns, more than 1,100 subjects, of which half were for public orders and half for protecting economic competition.

- During their annual meeting yesterday, shareholders of IPB bank approved changes to the bank's regulations which enable changes in the board as soon as the cabinet decides on a method of privatisation. Finance Minister Ivan Pilip confirmed that the cabinet will decide on the privatisation in the next few weeks.
- Insurance company Ceska Kooperativa had net profits last year of 13.1 million crowns. Shareholders decided to increase basic capital from 226.5 million crowns to 450 million.

PRAVO - Leaders of coalition parties and the opposition Social Democrats assured President Vaclav Havel during a meeting on Thursday that they are in favour of the Czech Republic's entry into NATO, according to Havel.
- A regional court in Usti nad Labem on Tursday ruled that agents of the company Madokar will be sent to prison for eight years for illegal transactions with light heating oils.
- During the first five months of this year, exports of Czech beer amounted to 1.1 million hectolitres. There were 2.2 million hectolitres exported for the whole of last year.
- Brewery Velke Popovice will cover its losses of 149 million crowns from last year with future profits. It will not pay a dividend for 1996.
- Vertex, the largest Czech manufacturer of glass fibres and filaments, will pay a gross dividend of 20 crowns per share from 1996 net profit of 201 million crowns.
- Transporta Chrudim obtained a four-billion-crown order in St. Petersburg to reconstruct the MPBO factory, which processes communal waste.

LIDOVE NOVINY - Although all coalition representatives on the parliament budgetary committee supported easing taxes for legal subjects from 39 to 33 percent, the Christian Democrats now condition their approval of this on whether a vote among 18 representatives of the party approves it.
- The Civic Democratic Alliance (ODA) proposes that all families with children should be given tax discounts, although the Civic Democratic Party (ODS) opposes this.
- Representatives of the city of Prague did not approve an increase basic capital for Prvni Mestska Banka, which was proposed by Mayor Jan Koukal.
-- Prague Newsroom, 420-2-2423-0003
